awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  The 2015 Taan Fiord landslide tsunami: An interdisciplinary study of cause & effect
awd_abstract_narration:
As glaciers retreat, the ice pressing up against their valley walls disappears. These rock walls then become unstable and can collapse in catastrophic landslides. In Alaska, where this phenomenon is increasingly common, landslides sometimes fall directly into the ocean and trigger a tsunami. This is what happened in October 2015 in the Taan Fiord: the largest rock avalanche in America in decades plunged 150 million tons of debris into the head of the fiord, producing a wave of water that ran 150m up the opposite bank and scoured the forested flanks of the fiord for at least 12km. The goal of the project is to collect observations of this Taan landslide and tsunami, and to deliver a benchmark dataset to the science and engineering communities so that they can better prepare for future disasters.

The project will combine satellite images, field observations and ship-based mapping to constrain the dynamics of the landslide and tsunami, including the mass and velocity of debris when it struck the water, the magnitude of tsunami wave generation and its pattern of motion, and the submarine flow of debris and its deposition. Data collection will take place in the summer of 2016 and will be delivered to the community by the winter.

por.por_cntn:
On October 17th, 2015, the largest landslide in North America in decades struck the head of Taan Fiord, an arm of Icy Bay in southeast Alaska, triggering a tsunami that was detected on tide gauges over 400 km away. The landslide was initially detected using the global network of seismometers and a technique developed at LDEO/Columbia University. Our project focused on understanding the effects of the landslide and tsunami through a combination of satellite, airborne and ground-based remote sensing, along with ground mapping, and numerical modeling. The major goals of the project were to (1) study the subaerial landslide, including the source volume, and supraglacial debris sedimentology; (2) map the submarine landslide, including determination of the deposited volume and extent, flow patterns and any internal structures; (3) map the tsunami traces, including submarine and subaerial morphology, trimlines, etc; (4) map and sample tsunami deposits; (5) evaluate glacier response to the landslide impact; (6) evaluate fjord circulation and sedimentation response to landslide impacts; and (7) evaluate predictions made using the teleseismic method, including bulk mass, direction of motion, etc. We found that the tsunami was one of the largest in decades, and most of the landslide is buried beneath remobilized fjord floor sediments.

 


Last Modified: 08/17/2018
Modified by: Daniel Shugar
